sourceDesc.p: Born digital. Words and definitions taken from the revised digital lexis at . Pronunciation information taken from the Hope Pronunciation Guide. Commentary added.

projectDesc.p: Comprehensive linguistic reference for the various LANGDEV languages.

namespace.name: http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0
namespace.tagUsage: Used to separate the different versions of the Lrex language, and also to contain preface material.
The class type marks a Lrex version 6 word class.
The BCP47 type marks an IETFInternet Engineering Task Force language tag, as defined by BCPBest Current Practices 47.
The version type is used to denote versions in the list of changes.
The unicode type is used to reference a Unicode character.
The splash type refers to an optional splash quote. A splash with subtype default identifies the default splash; all others are alternates.

html:footer.html:p:
Written in TEI and styled as HTML using XSLT+CSS.

revisionDesc.change: Rewrote LRECLexisMLLexis Markup Language index RECord+HTMLHyperText Markup Language dictionary files into a single TEIText Encoding Initiative document. Corrections were made where errors were found and documentation was improved. 2.01
Created LRECLexisMLLexis Markup Language index RECord+HTMLHyperText Markup Language dictionary files, including frontmatter, from the original source documents. 1.01

div.p: Lrex is an early culture and language in the Jastu-Sevensi language family. Most of the words in the known Lrex lexicon pertained to feelings or emotions, as these are the words which went on to influence later languages. Lrex is highly onomatopœic and features a large number of vowels.

The words below are grouped into six generations based on their approximate times of origin. The earliest of these are categorized as Lrex version 1 and the latest as Lrex version 6. As most of the influence on later Jastu-Sevensi languages occured around the time of Lrex version 5, our knowledge of Lrex version 6 is incomplete.

Definitive etymological classifications for Lrex words have not been made. However, in the later Lrex versions, broad associations have been noted. These are marked via a U+223B ∻ HOMOTHETIC Unicode character below.

As Lrex is in essence a speculative proto-language, the pronunciation data should not be taken as anything more than a broad guideline. However, given an American English dialect, the following pronunciation key may be helpful:

list.item: Like the first e in enter
Similar to œ, above, except with the ē sound replaced with ī

div.p: Lrex has been given the language code art-x-lrx. As with any language using the art tag, specifying the Latn script may prove useful. Lrex has no known native script.

entry.def: of or pertaining to a thing
